data.body: BTW if you just have a glTF model and want to very quickly make sure it's exported correctly from your editor, you can drag-and-drop it here: https://gltf-viewer.donmccurdy.com/ (which tests against r89)
@looeee it looks like FBXLoader is doing the same thing as GLTFLoader here, and using `setPath()` only for extra resources. Any idea if that has been discussed before somewhere?

> Well, I would argue, that if setPath() is available on a loader, it should function in the same way, as the other loaders do ...

It looks like other loaders are not consistent either... I _think_ the purpose of `setPath()` is just for when you have extra resources in a different folder than your original model, and otherwise you don't need to use it. In which case GLTFLoader is doing the right thing. But I'm not sure that's how it's intended to work.

It's a matter of software design ...
FileLoader as a Base class, from which all other Loaders are deriving

Well, except that Loader is already the base class, not FileLoader, and FileLoader never has to deal with extra resources... and if we did that, it would not be possible to load textures from a different folder than the base file, which is the main point I think. Perhaps we should rename the method `setResourcePath` or even remove it since `setUrlModifier()` can do the same thing now, but that would be a breaking change..

Some model file formats have e.g. texture links included, which additionally complicates this issue.
That's why some format have "all resources included", e.g. blender, threejs format version 4, as far as I know.

> Some model file formats have e.g. texture links included, which additionally complicates this issue.

True, FBX and glTF have that as well. Fortunately I think that's the easiest case here. 😁

> @looeee it looks like FBXLoader is doing the same thing as GLTFLoader here, and using `setPath()` only for extra resources. Any idea if that has been discussed before somewhere?

Interestingly, `MTLLoader` also has a `setTexturePath()`... https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/examples/js/loaders/MTLLoader.js#L74-L78

I've renamed the issue *Loaders: Inconsistent implementations of .setPath()*, as I think the changes to consider would be:

1. [ ] Ensuring that all loaders use `setPath()` for extra resources but not the original request.
2. [ ] Deprecate `setPath()` on FileLoader and ImageLoader, as they have no extra resources.
3. [ ] Consider renaming `setPath()` in cases where it must behave differently than this, renaming the normal case to `setResourcePath()`, or similar clarification.

I think in the "loaders class tree", there are even more inconsistencies as well;
if I only focus on .obj and .gltf, there are differences in the granularity of the returned interface objects,
eg.:
- OBJLoader.load   returns a _group_ object
- OBJLoader2.load returns _object.detail.loaderRootNode_ (= group)
- GLTFLoader.load returns another _"compound object"_ ...

BTW, another issue I found out: it seems as if there is no ability of loading just & only points ...
You can export **Points** (= a PointCloud (without faces/uvs)) with Blender,
but no way to import these Points in threejs, as far as i have seen for now.

The differences in returned values have various reasons, some intentional some probably not... glTF may contain more than just a model, so a `THREE.Group` is not sufficient. Feel free to open a new issue to suggest changes, but I think it's too complex a thing to discuss in this thread.

About points, could you open a new issue describing what you've tried that isn't working? Some formats support points, other formats do not. Formats that support points may not necessarily return _only_ a `THREE.Points` object, e.g. glTF would return that something like this:

```
{
  scene: <THREE.Scene>,
  ...
{
```

.... where the `scene` entry contains one or more `THREE.Points` objects as children or grand-children.

I'm not sure if it's the same issue you're facing, but I'm already aware of that `GLTFLoader` can't handle(display) `Points` correctly.

The reason is `GLTFLoader` doesn't create `PointsMaterial` for `Points`. `Points` needs `PointsMaterial` to be rendered. It can't be rendered with `Mesh*Material` (If I'm right).

I already started to work on it in my local branch.

Another issue I'm aware of is glTF doesn't hold point size information. I'm gonna ask or open an issue to glTF team (if necessary).

As @donmccurdy mentioned, please open an issue if what I mentioned aren't what you ran into.

@donmccurdy, @takahirox: Many THX for your responses so far!

Don has recently "widened" the issue concern,
if you go one step further, it could even become: _loaders - code quality / orthogonal code testing_

I mean something like (pseudo code):

```
for each available model-loader:
   load (her specific format) export file/model, containing 1 point / 1 edge / ... / 1 (default) cube / ... / complex model into her scene
   //additional tests cases: apply any loader methods ...
   for all renderers:
      render(),
      then look, if her scene has become rendered her model as expected

```
I can write a 
- test case to accomplish that (in the coding style of e.g. _examples/webgl_multiple_elements.html_), or 
- write unit tests (like _test/unit/editor/Loader.tests.js_)

I found (in docs, wiki) no development directive, which of these three.js/mrdoob does prefer ? ...

Concerning **Points**, I'll open a new issue or PR, as you suggested ...
Beforehand: The most minimal model is IMO 1 Point/1 Vertex/no materials,
e.g. 1_point.obj
```
# zero point
v 0 0 0
# maybe plus
p 1

```
which could be rendered by THREE.Points / gl.drawArrays(gl.POINTS, ...), taken any default material/fragm. shader.
In my tests with any loaders, I could'nt find that zero point, oh no ;-)

I'd like to move back to the original topic, loader's `.setPath` inconsistency. We can make another issue for another inconsistency.

My opinion is

- `.setPath` for loading original file. Path for original file wouldn't be really necessary but we don't need to break the compatibility. And using `.setPath` like this https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/examples/webgl_materials_cars.html#L169-L171 looks very simple and clear.
- And `.setResourcePath`, `.setTexturePath` or something which clearly explains what path is for.  The method name `.setPath` for extra resource is a bit lack of information.

@takahirox how about this...

* `.setPath` applies to the original file.
* `.setResourcesPath` if set, we apply it to resources, otherwise we use the path from `.setPath`.

PS: Yes, I prefer `.setResourcesPath` (plural) instead of `.setResourcePath`. 
PS2: `.setTexturesPath` also sounds better than `.setResourcesPath`.
Actually, the singular form, `.setTexturePath`, sounds best to me for some reason...

Note that it is not just for textures — resources could include `.bin` files for glTF, audio and script files for SEA3D, animation files for MMD, ... but MTLLoader does already use a `.setTexturePath` method for one example.

Another way to simplify might be deprecating `.setPath` on loaders that have no external resource files.
I vote for @mrdoob suggestion. Having two methods, one for the main file and a second one for additional resources. But I would choose `setResourcePath()` as the method name.

Sorry I wrote poorly but what I proposed is same as what @mrdoob suggested. I implied 

> .setResourcesPath if set, we apply it to resources, otherwise we use the path from .setPath.

I think what we should decide here are

1. Whether we need `.setPath` or not for original data
2. Singular or plural for additional resources
3. Whether we need the same method name for additional resources or each loader can have different method name like `.setTexturePath` for `MTLLoader` while `.setResourcePath` for `GLTFLoader`.

Voting for

1. We keep `.setPath` so far
2. Singlar
3. Different method names

> I vote for @mrdoob suggestion. Having two methods, one for the main file and a second one for additional resources. But I would choose `setResourcePath()` as the method name.

`.setResourcePath` sounds good to you @WestLangley?

> 1. Whether we need `.setPath` or not for original data

I think so. Think of the `CubeTextureLoader` use case:
https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/examples/webgl_water.html#L128-L135

>.setResourcePath sounds good to you @WestLangley?

Sure.

What is left to do here? Is someone who is familiar with this issue willing to create a new post with a task list?

/ping @takahirox
/ping @donmccurdy
/ping @Mugen87

I also prefer `setResourcePath` over `setTexturePath` and the plural alternatives. Since resource is a generic term, I do not think we need an additional `setTexturePath` method for loaders where all of the resources happen to be textures, like MTLLoader. If we're agreed on that, the tasks are updating (all?) loaders such that:

* [ ] `.setPath()` affects original file (or multiple original files forCubeTextureLoader)
* [ ] `.setResourcePath()` affects dependencies of original file, where applicable

> > .setResourcePath() affects dependencies of original file, where applicable

It seems there is agreement. Who is willing to take responsibility for this task?
